title: Elisha's Miracles and Siege
shortSummary: 2 Kings 6 recounts miraculous events performed by the prophet Elisha, including the recovery of a lost axe head, divine protection against the king of Syria's armies, and the compassionate treatment of captured soldiers. The chapter also describes a severe famine during a Syrian siege of Samaria, highlighting God's sovereignty and the prophet's role in guiding and protecting Israel.
timeline: c. 850 BC - Period of the divided kingdom during the reigns of the kings of Israel and Syria

keyCharacters.name: Elisha
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of God who performs miracles and provides guidance and protection to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: King of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The ruler of Israel who receives warnings and counsel from Elisha.

keyCharacters.name: King of Syria (Benhadad)
keyCharacters.description: The enemy king who wages war against Israel and besieges Samaria.

keyCharacters.name: Servant of Elisha
keyCharacters.description: Elisha’s attendant who witnesses the spiritual realities behind the Syrian army’s attack.

definitions.definition: Groups of prophetic disciples or students who lived communally and were trained under a prophet like Elisha.
A large piece of timber used in construction, here for building a dwelling place.
A divine manifestation of heavenly warriors or angels protecting God's prophet and people.
A military blockade of a city or fortress to force surrender, often causing famine and hardship.

outline.heading: The Sons of the Prophets Build a New Dwelling and the Axe Head Miracle
outline.description: The sons of the prophets seek more space and build a new place by the Jordan. When an axe head falls into the water, Elisha miraculously causes it to float, demonstrating God's power over nature and concern for practical needs.

outline.heading: Elisha’s Divine Intelligence and Protection from the Syrian Army
outline.description: Elisha warns Israel’s king of Syrian military plans, frustrating the enemy. When the Syrians surround Dothan, Elisha reveals the heavenly army protecting them and blinds the invaders, leading to their peaceful release. This section highlights God's sovereignty and mercy.

outline.heading: The Siege of Samaria and the Famine’s Horrors
outline.description: Benhadad besieges Samaria, causing a severe famine with tragic consequences. The desperate conditions reveal the dire effects of war and judgment, setting the stage for Elisha’s intervention.

outline.heading: Elisha’s Defiance and Trust in God’s Sovereignty
outline.description: Despite the king’s fear and threats against Elisha, the prophet remains confident that the calamity is from the Lord and trusts God’s timing, encouraging believers to rely on God amid trials.

application: Trust in God's providence and power even when circumstances seem overwhelming, as Elisha demonstrated in the face of enemy armies.
Pray for spiritual insight and courage to see beyond visible troubles, remembering that God’s protection often surrounds us unseen.
Show mercy and kindness to others, including enemies, reflecting God's compassion as Elisha did with the blinded Syrian soldiers.
Remain faithful and patient during trials, trusting that God is sovereign over all events, even when judgment and hardship come.

keyVerses.text: And he answered, Fear not: for they that be with us are more than they that be with them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encourages believers to trust God's greater power and presence in times of fear and danger.

keyVerses.text: And Elisha prayed, and said, LORD, I pray thee, open his eyes, that he may see. And the LORD opened the eyes of the young man; and he saw: and, behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire round about Elisha.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals the spiritual reality of God's protection and the unseen heavenly forces guarding His people.

keyVerses.text: And he prepared great provision for them: and when they had eaten and drunk, he sent them away, and they went to their master. So the bands of Syria came no more into the land of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the power of mercy and peace over violence, leading to lasting security for Israel.

keyVerses.text: And while he yet talked with them, behold, the messenger came down unto him: and he said, Behold, this evil is of the LORD; what should I wait for the LORD any longer?
keyVerses.significance: It highlights Elisha’s recognition of God’s sovereign control over judgment and the call to trust His timing.
